div.head:
Embleme 37. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Three things are sufficient for the Magistery, the white fume, that
is, water, the green Lyon, that is, the brasse of Hermes, and aqua
fætida.

lg.l: The Lyon green, white fume, and stinking juice,
Are all that to our ProcesseProcess doe conduce:
Water the mother is oth'of the Elements,
And the sole matter of the Sophicke Ens.
This Lyon is th'the Hermeticke Stone and Brasse,
And the white fume a watrywatery nature has.

div.head: Discourse 37.
div.ab:
As three essentiall things, which are the foundation, walls, and roofe, are
required to the building of every ædificeedifice, whereof one being absent, there
can be noe perfection of it, soeso are soeso many desired in order to-
complete the Philosophers compound, which are here named by their
proper names: The author of Aurora, chapt. 20. speaking of the Se
paration of the Elements, Sayth, Earth is left in the same place, that
the other three Elements may be radicated in it; if it were not for
that, the Elements could have noe foundation to build upon it a new
jewelljewel house: This foundation is here called Aqua fætida, which is
the mother of all the Elements, wittnessewitness Rosarius, from which, and
by which, and with which the Philosophers doe præpare it, that is,
the Elixir in the begining, and the end: It is called Aqua fætida,
because it sends forth a Sulphureous stinke, and the smell of Sepulchers:-
This is that water, which Pegasus strucke out of Parnassus with his hoofe,-
which Nonacris a mountaine of Arcadia producethproduces springing out of a-
rocke at the top, which can onely be contained in the hoofe of a horse by
reason of its most excessive strength: This is that Dragons water, as Rosa
rius calls it, which ought to be made by an Alembicke, without adding-
any other thing, in the making of which there is an extraordinary stinke:
Which words some having heard betookebetook themselves to distill the dung of
men or other animalls, in which operation they did indeed feele a most-
vehement stinke, but found dung in the dung: But thinke not the Phi
losophers to be Beetles, which operate in dung, you must know that the stinke,
if there be any, is presently changed into great fragrancy, as Lully asserts
of his Quintessence, to which hee ascribes such a sweetnesse of savoursavor, if
it be rightly made, that being placed at the top of a house, it allures-
birds flying to it, and causethcauses them to stand: But hee puts his Quintessence
in dung, by the most temperate heat of which that fragrancy followes,-
which some men having tryed with strong wine, but in vainevain, did there
fore accuse Lully of vanity, whereas themselves ought rather to be-
reproved of folly, who never tasted Lullye'sLully's wine; but that golden Po
et better understood Lully, who in his first booke of Aurifaction thus sings:
At non ille quidem sensit, quæ dicere prima
Est facie visus, neq tum stillantia vina
Miscebat, Ct.
Hee thought not what at first hee seemdseemed to say,
Nor then mixd stilling wines, Ct.
After Aqua fætida comes the green Lyon: concerning which sayth Ro
sarius; you have sought for greennessegreenness, supposing, that brasse was a-
leprous body, because of that greenessegreenness which it hath: and therefore-
I declare to you, that whatsoever is perfect in brasse, is that greenessegreenness
Discourse 37.
alone, which is in it: because that greenessegreenness is by our Magistery suddenly
turned into our most true gold, and this wee have had experience of:
yet you can noe way præpare the Stone without Duenech green and
liquid, which is seen to spring in our Mynes: O blessed greenessegreenness,-
which dostdoes generate all things: From whence you must know, that-
noe vegetable, and noe fruit appears to germinate without a green-
colour: in like manner you must know, that the generation of this thing is
green, wherefore the Philosophers call it the bud. These are the words of
Rosarius: This is the Philosophers gold, and brasse, and Stone noted in-
the Chapters, a fume, vapour and water, the Spittle of Luna, which is joynd
to the light of Sol; This green Lyon fights with the Dragon, but is by him
overcome, and in length of time devoured; and the Lyon being putrefyed
sweetnesse is expected to proceed from his mouth, as being SlayneSlain by Sampson:
The Dragon getting the upper hand soeso fills himselfe with the Lyons-
flesh, as to burst a little and dye: Of which, the fatt alone of a Lyon curing
quotidian FeaversFevers, and grace and favour being obtained between Kings-
and people anoyntedanointed therewith, a most excellent medicine may be made,
very coḿodious for many maladyes. In the third place followes-
the white fume, which, if it be coagulated, becomes water,
and performs the office of water in washing, dissolving, and
taking away spots like SoupeSoup: This is that fire against na
ture, which see that you find, soeso called, because it is-
contrary to nature undoing and destroying that, which She
with diligent care compounded: This fire is not kindled as
the Spirit of wind or oyle, but as an incombustible matter, of-
æquall duration and heat, and is a fire without light and combusti
on of great virtue and efficacy, which to find in darkenesse is a
thing of noe little difficulty, because it shines not, but of much
greater to apply rightly to the worke; the circumstances and-
propertyes of which wee have sufficiently in severall places de
scribed. . . . . . . . . . . . . .
